Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ARI-LA: Low-Dose Inspection for Nuclear Threats Using Monochromatic Gamma-Rays

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Low-dose inspection for nuclear threats using monochromatic gamma-rays is a novel method to detect shielded nuclear material (SNM) with a potential to significantly outperform currently employed methods. The key advantage of the method we are pursuing is in low dose (<20 mrad), ability for high-speed screening, accuracy in identification of nuclear materials, and relatively low cost and simplicity in design and operation. The advantages are achievable through use of ultra-compact superconducting accelerator technology applied to sources development, which can be tailored to produce multiple monoenergetic gamma rays and/or neutrons. Furthermore, monoenergetic sources coupled with the development of advanced radiation detectors and a new information science-driven approach for system design and data analysis have a potential to create unprecedented performance of the system in view of safety, efficiency and accuracy.

The unique and innovative approach to the design is the enabling factor for future SNM detection technologies. Integration of the novel method of monoenergetic source generation through use of a new generation of ultra-compact accelerators with advanced imaging detectors has a potential for a paradigm shift in the ability to rapidly and accurately clear objects from nuclear threats. Moreover, this interdisciplinary work requires a broad combined expertize in the areas of compact hadron accelerators, monochromatic gamma-ray sources, detectors, and algorithms making our team particularly well-suited for the task. This research combines several new and high-risk ideas and, if successful, could bring about revolutionary advances in the methods to detect shielded SNM, with broad impacts and benefits to the welfare and security of the nation and society and promote the diversity and public understanding of science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Special nuclear material (SNM) refers to materials that can be used to construct a nuclear explosive device. Even small (few-kilogram) quantities of SNM are sufficient for this purpose, which has prompted special attention to ensure that all cargo traffic is monitored for presence of SNM. While SNM spontaneously produces signatures that could be used to detect its presence, those signatures are weak and can be readily shielded. For those reasons, the detection of shielded SNM is considered the grand challenge of nuclear security.

In our collaborative project we are exploring the detection of shielded SNM by use of active interrogation (AI), which refers to inducing a stronger specific signature of SNM by means of an external radiation probe. Novel aspects of our approach include the use of new AI sources (low-energy nuclear reactions), new radiation detectors, and new methods for measurements and analysis. Our research spans all of these aspects, with emphasis on the development of novel neutron detectors.

Our novel neutron detectors are based on a composite of scintillating polymer (polyvinyl toluene, PVT) and lithium-doped glass. By careful design of the detector geometry, the detector based on the principle of combining two materials with dissimilar properties can achieve special characteristics useful for the detection of shielded SNM. Specifically, this design is particularly suitable for detecting one signature of SNM that is normally difficult to detect in a typical high-radiation AI environment – the relatively low-energy delayed neutrons that accompany the fission of SNM.

This is a multi-year project supported jointly by National Science Foundation for one year and Department of Homeland Security for four years. The NSF-supported first year of the project led to several major accomplishments, including the completion of the model and design for a composite detector, experimental development of a novel detector geometry that includes thin lithium-doped glass rods, and major advances in fabrication techniques which resulted in successful fabrication of a subscale prototype detector (see attached figure). This detector has been successfully tested using radioisotopes neutron sources, and a very high figure of merit has been demonstrated. Finally, we tested our prototype detector in AI environment (low-energy nuclear reaction source at the MIT Bates Accelerator Center) and demonstrated preliminary detection of the sought delayed neutron signature.

These accomplishments set the stage for successful transition of the project to the Department of Homeland Security sponsorship. Over the remaining period of the project our goal is to refine the detector design and integrate it with other components of a detection system. This will allow us to investigate the potential of an integrated suite of sources, detectors, and algorithms to realize advances in AI for shielded SNM detection. Such advance could have broad benefits to nuclear security both nationally and globally.
